Does anyone know what has happened to the Honey Bees? I was walking my dog in a large field of clover the other day and did not see one Bee. Normally, the field would have been covered in Bees. I have seen no more than 10 Honey Bees in my area this spring. No Bees, no pollination, no pollination no food. Where are the Bees?

lord tammerlain

I believe there is a parasite that is killing off a large number of bees. 
 
 http://www.freerepublic.com/focus/f-news/1372379/posts
 
 
 
 The varroa mite has killed or severely weakened an estimated 40 percent to 60 percent of honeybees in the United States during the past six months.
daewoo

I know aboslutly nothing about beekeeping, though I have a couple of hives hanging on the back of my barn to pollinate cherry trees and flowers and such (VERY common around here). A guy from town comes and tends them and takes the honey out of them (I think). 
 
 I lost one of the hives to the mite. It just started to die. the guy who cares for them killed all the bees, burned the hive, and sprayed some kind of chemical stuff all over the area where the hiive stood, then we burned all the vegetation back there. Don't know yet if the other colony has the mites or not yet. No signs so far....
 
 Apparently it is a very serious problem. I have noticed that the "cherry crop" (We only have a few cherry trees anyway) is suffering badly, and I can only guess it is because the bees are gone and they are not getting pollinated very well. 
 
 I moved some peacocks out of the garden and have been feeding them back there, thinking that maybe they will eat the mites if any survived since I know they eat other kinds of mites. The jury is still out on whether that will work or not. Ag extension guy says maybe, beekeeper says yes. ag agent claims that routine spraying for th emites has allowed them to build a resistance to the insecticides we usually use to kill them.

 I am in Memphis, Tn. The weather has been great of late. I have noticed every other type of Bees and Wasps in great abundance. Seems like the Honey Bee has been declining in numbers around these parts for several years, but this is the first year that you have to hunt for them to find them. You can do it manually using a small camel hair brush, available at any art store.

 
 http://oregonstate.edu/Dept/NWREC/tomatogh.html
 
 http://www.gardenpower.com/projects/joes/02076.html
 
 http://www.attra.org/attra-pub/ghtomato.html
 
 http://www.pollinator.com/self_pollinating_tomato.htm
 
 The size of the fruit is dependent on the number of ovules fertilized, up to the 100% mark. In other words, the more seeds, the meatier the 'mater. So we want to get pollination as full as possible. This is the reason the bee is best, it delivers the most grains of pollen, exactly where it is needed, on the sticky surface of the stigma.
 
 When shaking is done by hand, think about mimicking the natural resonances of sonicating bees. Shaking should not be violent, just as close to the right frequency as possible. Electric vibrators were long used in greenhouses for tomatoes, but have been replaced, as bumblebees are found to be far more efficient. Using an artist brush with tomatoes is very inefficient because the pollen is not on the surface.
 
 Yup, tomatoes are self fertile, but self pollinating?...only when conditions are ideal...they often need help. "Self pollinating" is one of the myths of tomato growers.

Hard to beat the roadside stands here where everything is grown organically, looks, tastes perfect and is rock-bottom cheap. By the early 1980s they said they could buy what they wanted, organically grown and to their standards, for less money than they could produce their home garden.

 Sorry, not "pepper"...."peppers". A lot of people grow peppers hydroponically. It is just abotu as cheap as growing them in dirt, but at the end of summer you can move your whole rig inside (mine goes in the sun room for the winter) and you have resh peppers year round. It is about 3x easier than growing in dirt, especially if you have a black thumb like yours truly. By being to exactly control the nutrients, you get a bigger yield (my plants produce more that twice what my mother in laws do, and she is actually good at growing things) and better control of plant development.
 
 Some of you tomato folks should try it. If you ar enot up to building your own system, there are commercially produced systems for 6-8 plants avaliable for very little money. You could have fresh tomatos year round.

 I grow tomatoes and hot peppers for my home-made salsa. I've noticed that my 'maters aren't growing as big or as plentiful as they have in years past despite some seriously-fertile soil. Maybe I'll try hydroponics. It never fails that I have my biggest yield of green tomatoes right before the first frost, too.
 No matter how hard I try, there's still no substitute for Jersey tomatoes bought from roadside stands in South Jersey. I'd kill for them. :)
gnojek

As a child were your surroundings more rural than developed compared to your present residence?

 Um, I guess it was less developed, and in a different state.
 After made that post, later I called a relative about it who lives around Port Arthur, Texas.
 
 They said it was really hot down there right now and that there were plenty of dragonflies. Supposedly the hotter and more humid it is, the more they come out.
 
 So I was concerned about nothing, I guess.

Maybe I'll try hydroponics. It never fails that I have my biggest yield of green tomatoes right before the first frost, too.
 No matter how hard I try, there's still no substitute for Jersey tomatoes bought from roadside stands in South Jersey. I'd kill for them. :)

 
 
 Give it a shot. I am on my laptop right now so do not have the binift of my bookmarks, but a goolge search should net you plenty of info, including suppliers of home sized hydroponic setups. My favorite is built from a bug green sotage tub that I got at wal mart ($7). The whole thing is self contained, and holds a dozen plants. You just plug it in (the pump has to run) and that is all there is too it. In the spring, after threat of frost ahs passed, I carry it ouside and drop it in a planter in the garden that is made to fit. In the fall/winter it sits on our sun porch. Fresh peppers year round with no hassle. That is my kind of gardening.
 
 A couple places sell the units like the one I built. They are $150-$250, and take a month to ship. I didn't want to wait that long, so I went to wally world, dropped $20 all together, and built 2 of them in about an hour. If you look at the pics, you will quickly see how they go together. 
 
 Last fall I started soem tomato plants for my mother in law, who is addicted to the thing. Fresh tomatos in december. you can't beat that. The only differnce she has noticed is that they are bigger and have a better flavor than soil grown ones
